elements.title: Surface Hidden Host Rules as Visible Platform Feedback
elements.problem: Experienced hosts carry non-standard rules they have developed from painful past experiences -- utility caps with conditional thresholds, personal vetting requirements beyond platform defaults, cross-platform calendar blocking obligations. These rules are invisible to the platform unless the host explicitly states them during a call. The platform has no structured way to capture, confirm, or enforce conditional rules like a $40 utility cap with guest-paid overage. When these rules are not visibly encoded, the host cannot verify the platform is protecting them, and trust erodes silently. June asked about the same fee rule twice in one call because the verbal feedback did not persist, demonstrating that one-time explanations fail for critical rules.
elements.solution: Design every host-defined rule as a structured microinteraction with three components: (1) A capture mechanism that accepts conditional logic, not just binary toggles. The utility cap needs a threshold field ($40), an owner-responsibility indicator, and an overage-assignment field, not just 'utilities included: yes/no'. (2) Immediate confirmation feedback that mirrors the host's own language. After the host enters '$40 cap, guest pays overage,' the platform displays 'You cover the first $40 of electric. Your guest pays anything above that.' (3) Persistent visibility: every rule the host defined must remain visible on the listing, the proposal, and the active lease dashboard. Critical rules should appear as persistent indicators, not one-time confirmation toasts. Saffer's principle applies: feedback illuminates the rules, and rules that are not illuminated do not exist from the user's perspective.

evidence.quote: The electric bill, because people have been ridiculous with the electric bill, I believe it's only covered up to 40, the first $40 I pay and they have to pay different... I have had bills of a hundred, $200... I had to start protecting myself cause it was getting too much.
evidence.insight: The utility cap is not a preference -- it is a learned protection mechanism born from repeated painful experiences. The platform must treat this as a non-negotiable rule with enforcement, not as an optional data field.

evidence.quote: Are there any fees? Anything? No. [asked identically twice in the same call]
evidence.insight: Verbal feedback does not persist. The same critical question was asked twice because the answer did not produce durable memory. Platform feedback for critical rules must be persistent and visually scannable, not ephemeral.

evidence.source: microinteractions-rules-feedback.txt, Ch. 4, Feedback Illuminates the Rules, p. 86
evidence.quote: Feedback Illuminates the Rules.
evidence.insight: Saffer's core principle: users understand what a system does through its feedback, not through its documentation. Every hidden rule June carries (utility cap, vetting, calendar blocking) must be illuminated through persistent visual feedback on every screen where that rule is relevant.

evidence.quote: Rules define the hidden parameters of how a microinteraction works... Don't Start from Zero.
evidence.insight: The platform's rule structure must accommodate conditional and parameterized rules (threshold + owner responsibility + overage assignment), not just binary states. Starting from the host's existing rule set (imported from call or other platforms) rather than blank fields is essential.

elements.user_goal: Know that every rule I set for my property is captured exactly as I stated it, visible to guests, and enforced by the platform without requiring me to monitor or re-explain it.
elements.company_goal: Reduce host distrust and support-contact volume by making host-defined rules self-documenting and self-enforcing, eliminating the need for repeated verbal clarification.
elements.time_budget: 2 seconds to scan and verify each rule on any screen where it appears. 30 seconds to define a new conditional rule during listing creation.
anti_goals: DO NOT reduce conditional rules to binary toggles. 'Utilities included: yes/no' cannot capture a $40 threshold with guest-paid overage.
DO NOT display rule confirmations as temporary toast notifications that disappear. Critical rules must be persistently visible.
DO NOT use platform jargon to restate host rules. If the host said '$40 cap,' the platform should display '$40 cap,' not 'utility allocation threshold' or 'variable surcharge parameter.'
DO NOT require the host to re-explain rules when extending a lease or listing a second property. Rules should propagate and be editable, not re-entered.
elements.success_metric: Percentage of hosts who define at least one conditional rule during listing creation and can verify that rule is accurately displayed on their published listing within 5 seconds of checking. Target: 90%.

elements.title: Inherit Agent Trust into Platform Through Continuity of Trigger
elements.problem: June's entire relationship with Split Lease is mediated by Bryant. Discovery happened because Bryant called. Evaluation happened because Bryant answered questions. Onboarding was promised as 'I'll create the listings and send you a link.' June's recognized trigger for every interaction is Bryant, not the platform. When the platform introduces its own triggers (email notifications, dashboard alerts, login screens), it breaks the trigger consistency that Saffer identifies as essential: 'Have the trigger initiate the same action every time. This is so users can create an accurate mental model of how the microinteraction works.' June's mental model is 'I text Bryant and things happen.' The platform's model is 'log in, navigate, and do things yourself.' This mismatch creates a trust gap at the human-to-digital handoff -- the highest-risk transition in the host journey.
elements.solution: Design the platform's first triggers to feel like extensions of the agent, not replacements. (1) The first email from the platform should come from Bryant's name and include his photo, not from 'noreply@splitlease.com.' (2) The first screen the host sees should show Bryant's name, the properties discussed, and the terms confirmed during the call. The platform should feel like opening notes from someone you just talked to. (3) The listing review screen should be framed as 'Bryant created this listing from your Furnished Finder info. Review and confirm.' not 'Create your listing.' (4) The platform should preserve the agent as a visible, contactable presence on every screen during the first lease cycle. The agent trigger that the host already trusts must transfer to the platform, not be replaced by it. Over time, as the host builds direct trust with the platform through successful transactions, the agent presence can become more ambient.

evidence.quote: I'll get those listings created. I can send you an email with a link to our site and you can expect that shortly after the call.
evidence.insight: The entire onboarding is promised as a one-way delivery from Bryant. June expects to receive a finished product to review, not to create from scratch. The platform's first trigger must match this expectation.

evidence.quote: I been going through a lot of stuff myself. I'm sorry... No worries. I can send you my email, and if you have any questions or anything, you can email me whenever.
evidence.insight: June is personally depleted. Her fallback trigger is Bryant ('email me whenever'). The platform must not compete with this trigger but extend it -- messages from the platform should feel like messages from Bryant.

evidence.quote: Make the trigger something the target users will recognize as a trigger in context... Have the trigger initiate the same action every time. This is so users can create an accurate mental model of how the microinteraction works.
evidence.insight: June's recognized trigger is Bryant. The platform must present its triggers in the context of that existing relationship. If the trigger changes from 'text Bryant' to 'log in to dashboard,' the mental model breaks and the host reverts to the known trigger.

evidence.quote: Triggers need not be user-initiated. Increasingly, triggers are system-initiated -- when the device or application itself detects that certain conditions have been met and begins a microinteraction.
evidence.insight: Split Lease's original outreach to June was a system trigger that failed (no email contact). The successful trigger was manual: Bryant's phone call. The platform's system triggers (notifications, alerts) must inherit credibility from the manual trigger that succeeded, by being visibly connected to Bryant.

elements.user_goal: Experience the platform as a continuation of my conversation with Bryant, not as a separate tool I have to learn independently.
elements.company_goal: Increase post-call platform engagement by reducing the trust gap at the human-to-digital handoff, converting agent-dependent hosts into platform-active hosts over time without forcing an abrupt transition.
elements.time_budget: The host should recognize the platform as connected to Bryant within 3 seconds of their first visit. The review-and-confirm flow for agent-created listings should take under 2 minutes.
anti_goals: DO NOT send the first platform communication from a generic or system address. The first trigger must carry the agent's identity.
DO NOT require account creation or login before showing the host what the agent prepared for them. Show value first, then ask for registration.
DO NOT remove the agent's visible presence from the platform until the host has completed at least one full lease cycle successfully.
DO NOT force the host to re-enter information that was discussed during the call. The platform's first interaction should be confirmation, not data entry.
elements.success_metric: Post-call platform visit rate: percentage of hosts who visit the platform within 48 hours of their first agent call. Target: 70%. Secondary: percentage of agent-created listings confirmed by the host without support contact. Target: 80%.

elements.title: Absorb Cross-Platform Complexity Instead of Exporting It to the Host
elements.problem: June operates on Furnished Finder, other unnamed platforms, and now potentially Split Lease. Each commitment to Split Lease creates immediate obligations on other platforms: calendar blocking, availability updates, double-booking prevention. June explicitly states guests 'have to decide quickly because I would have to block it on the different platforms I have it on.' The platform currently treats its own boundaries as the edges of the host's world. But the host's world extends across multiple platforms, and any process that ignores this reality creates hidden operational costs that compound with each booking. Saffer's principle of Absorb Complexity applies: the platform should handle the cross-platform coordination burden internally rather than passing it to the host as manual work.
elements.solution: Design processes that acknowledge and reduce the cross-platform operational burden. (1) During proposal acceptance, show the host a checklist or reminder of what needs to happen on other platforms: 'You mentioned you have this listed on Furnished Finder. Remember to block these dates there.' Even a simple reminder is better than silence. (2) Long-term: explore calendar sync integrations with major platforms (Furnished Finder, Airbnb iCal) so that accepting a booking on Split Lease automatically blocks the dates elsewhere. (3) During listing creation, import data from existing platform listings rather than requiring re-entry. If the host shares a Furnished Finder link, scrape or import the pricing, photos, and description. (4) Frame multi-platform management as a feature, not a problem. Show the host that Split Lease understands their multi-platform reality and is designed to reduce, not add to, their coordination burden.

evidence.quote: Tell them it's something they have to decide quickly because I would have to block it on the different platforms I have it on.
evidence.insight: Cross-platform calendar blocking is an immediate, real cost of accepting a booking. The platform's proposal flow ignores this cost entirely, leaving the host to manage it manually.

evidence.quote: I'll take the information from your other listings, but I'll send it over to you and you can, from there, you'd be able to change anything that didn't look right.
evidence.insight: Bryant manually absorbs the cross-platform data import complexity. The platform should systematize this: given a Furnished Finder link, auto-populate the Split Lease listing.

evidence.quote: Absorb Complexity.
evidence.insight: Saffer's principle: the system should handle complexity internally rather than passing it to the user. Cross-platform calendar blocking, data import, and availability sync are complexity that the platform must absorb.

evidence.source: microinteractions-rules-feedback.txt, Ch. 3, Don't Start from Zero, p. 64
evidence.quote: Don't Start from Zero.
evidence.insight: June has complete listings on other platforms. Starting from zero on Split Lease -- blank forms, no photos, no pricing -- violates this principle and multiplies the onboarding effort for every property.

elements.user_goal: Manage my properties across platforms without Split Lease adding to my coordination workload. Ideally, Split Lease reduces it.
elements.company_goal: Reduce the operational friction that prevents multi-platform hosts from actively using Split Lease, converting them from passive (agent-dependent) to active (platform-engaged) users.
elements.time_budget: Cross-platform actions triggered by a Split Lease booking (calendar blocking reminders or automatic sync) should require zero additional host effort if automated, or under 30 seconds of acknowledgment if manual.
anti_goals: DO NOT ignore the host's multi-platform reality. Treating Split Lease as the host's only platform creates blind spots in proposal and active lease management.
DO NOT require the host to manually re-enter data that already exists on another platform when a link or import path is available.
DO NOT make calendar sync a premium feature. Cross-platform coordination is a baseline need for the target user, not an upsell.
DO NOT surface cross-platform complexity as the host's problem. Even when automation is not possible, frame reminders and checklists as the platform helping, not the platform demanding.
elements.success_metric: Double-booking rate: percentage of accepted proposals that result in calendar conflicts on other platforms reported by hosts. Target: under 5%. Secondary: listing creation time for hosts who provide an existing platform link vs. those who create from scratch. Target: 60% faster with link import.

elements.title: Design Multi-Property Operations with Inherited Defaults
elements.problem: June owns a three-family house with at least two listable apartments and proactively offered to list both. Multi-property hosts face multiplicative friction: every listing step, every pricing field, every house rule entry must be repeated per property. If the first listing takes 10 minutes, the second should not take another 10 minutes -- but without inherited defaults, it does. June's utility cap, deposit amount, cleaning fee, and house rules apply to her entire building, not to individual units. The platform has no mechanism to distinguish shared attributes (building-level rules) from unit-specific attributes (floor, layout, rent). Saffer's principle of Limited Options and Smart Defaults applies: the second listing should pre-populate with the first listing's shared attributes and only prompt for what differs.
elements.solution: Design listing creation to support multi-property hosts through attribute inheritance. (1) When a host creates a second listing, pre-populate all fields from the first listing and highlight only what needs to change (unit number, floor, layout, rent). (2) Distinguish building-level attributes (address, house rules, utility policy, deposit) from unit-level attributes (floor, bedrooms, rent, photos). Building-level attributes should be set once and inherited by all units. (3) For pricing, allow building-wide rules (utility cap, cleaning fee, deposit) to be set at the property level and inherited by each unit, with per-unit override capability. (4) During the active lease phase, building-level rules (utility cap enforcement, house rules) should apply uniformly across all units without requiring per-unit configuration. (5) Retention flows should surface opportunities for unlisted units based on demand signals: 'We have 3 guests looking in Harlem this month. Want to list your second apartment?'

evidence.quote: It's something like join in with, and you can list both of my apartments.
evidence.insight: June proactively wants to list multiple properties. The platform should make this the easiest possible action, not a repetition of the full listing flow.

evidence.quote: The electric bill, because people have been ridiculous with the electric bill, I believe it's only covered up to 40, the first $40 I pay and they have to pay different.
evidence.insight: The utility cap is a building-level rule, not a unit-level rule. It applies to June's entire three-family house. The platform should capture this once and apply it to all units.

evidence.source: microinteractions-rules-feedback.txt, Ch. 3, Limited Options and Smart Defaults, p. 69
evidence.quote: Limited Options and Smart Defaults.
evidence.insight: For the second listing, the smart default should be 'same as your first listing.' The host should only need to specify what differs. This reduces the listing creation microinteraction from full-form to delta-only.

evidence.quote: Preventing Errors.
evidence.insight: When a host manually re-enters building-level data for a second listing, inconsistencies are inevitable (different utility cap phrasing, different deposit amounts). Inheriting building-level attributes prevents these errors by design.

elements.user_goal: List all my properties without repeating myself. Set building-wide rules once and have them apply everywhere.
elements.company_goal: Increase listings-per-host by reducing the marginal cost of each additional listing from full-effort to incremental-effort, capturing the multi-property host segment that currently under-lists.
elements.time_budget: The second listing for a multi-unit host should take under 2 minutes if the first listing is already complete. Building-level rules should be settable once in under 30 seconds.
anti_goals: DO NOT require multi-property hosts to repeat the full listing creation flow for each unit. The second listing should be a delta, not a duplicate.
DO NOT allow building-level rules to diverge silently across units. If the host changes the utility cap, they should be asked whether to apply it to all units or just this one.
DO NOT treat multi-property management as a power-user feature behind an advanced settings wall. Many hosts in the target market own multi-family buildings.
DO NOT surface demand signals for unlisted properties before the host has had a successful first lease. Retention timing matters.
elements.success_metric: Second-listing creation time compared to first-listing creation time. Target: second listing under 40% of first listing duration. Secondary: listings-per-host for multi-property owners. Target: 1.8+ average.

elements.title: Design Active Lease Monitoring as an Adaptive Long Loop
elements.problem: June's most emotionally charged concern is utility abuse during active leases. She has experienced bills of $100-200 from guests leaving heat on with windows open. Her $40 cap is a protective rule, but the platform has no mechanism to monitor, report, or enforce it during the lease. Saffer identifies that recurring microinteractions (long loops) must evolve over time: 'What happens over time with the microinteraction?' A utility monitoring loop that stays static for 3+ months will either become noise (if the guest complies) or miss escalation signals (if the guest exceeds the cap repeatedly). Additionally, June mentions a roommate replacement scenario that is a mode shift within the active lease -- from stable occupancy to replacement -- requiring its own trigger, rules, and feedback structure.
elements.solution: Design the active lease as a long loop with adaptive feedback intensity. (1) Utility monitoring should provide a monthly summary visible to the host showing actual usage vs. the cap threshold. If the guest stays under the cap for consecutive months, the feedback becomes more ambient (a green indicator). If they exceed it, the feedback escalates (alert with overage amount and automatic guest notification). (2) Payment confirmation should arrive as a persistent, recurring signal each payment cycle -- not just the absence of a problem, but positive confirmation: 'Payment of $2,690 received and deposited for February.' This is especially critical for the payment guarantee promise. (3) The long loop should get quieter over time for compliant leases (reducing notification frequency) and louder for problematic ones (increasing alert urgency). (4) Mode shifts like roommate replacement should have clear entry triggers (guest departure notification), defined rules (new vetting, lease modification), and confirmation feedback (replacement confirmed, lease continuity guaranteed).

evidence.quote: I have had bills of a hundred, $200. I was like, what are you doing in the apartment?... the heat is on while the windows are open. They're not home, running, you know, all of that stuff. So I had to start protecting myself cause it was getting too much.
evidence.insight: Utility monitoring is not a nice-to-have -- it is the primary anxiety driver during the active lease. The host is vigilant because past experiences taught her that unmonitored tenants cause financial harm.

evidence.quote: No tenants. They basically found a new roommate and they just stayed and they just kept looking.
evidence.insight: Roommate replacement is a real active-lease event. It requires its own microinteraction structure: notification trigger, new vetting rules, and confirmation feedback that the lease continues without interruption.

evidence.quote: Long Loops.
evidence.insight: Active leases are inherently long loops lasting months. Saffer's guidance on long loops applies: the microinteraction must evolve over time, becoming more efficient and adaptive based on accumulated behavior data.

evidence.source: microinteractions-rules-feedback.txt, Ch. 5, Spring-Loaded and One-off Modes, p. 111-113
evidence.quote: Modes... Spring-Loaded and One-off Modes.
evidence.insight: Roommate replacement is a spring-loaded mode: it activates when a guest departs and deactivates when a replacement is confirmed. The platform must handle this mode transition with clear triggers and feedback, not leave it as an unstructured event.

elements.user_goal: Know throughout the lease that my rules are being enforced, my payments are arriving, and any disruptions (roommate changes, utility overages) are being handled with clear communication.
elements.company_goal: Increase host retention by providing continuous, low-friction confirmation that the platform is delivering on its guarantees, converting first-lease hosts into repeat users.
elements.time_budget: Monthly lease status should be scannable in under 5 seconds. Utility overage alerts should arrive within 24 hours of the bill exceeding the threshold. Payment confirmations should arrive on the day of deposit.
anti_goals: DO NOT rely on silence as positive feedback. 'No news is good news' does not build trust with hosts who have been burned before. Active confirmation is required.
DO NOT send identical monthly notifications. The long loop should adapt: quieter for stable leases, more detailed for ones with issues.
DO NOT handle roommate replacements as a new booking. It is a mode shift within an existing lease and should preserve continuity of all terms.
DO NOT burden the host with utility monitoring responsibility. The platform promised a guarantee; the monitoring should be the platform's job, with the host receiving reports, not raw data.
elements.success_metric: Host-initiated support contacts about payment status or utility issues during active leases. Target: under 10% of active leases generate a support contact per month. Secondary: host retention rate (second lease or second property listing) for hosts who completed a full active lease. Target: 60%.

elements.title: Make Proposal Review a Single-Screen Verification of All Host Rules
elements.problem: June's proposal evaluation requires verifying multiple conditions simultaneously: guest vetting status, pricing accuracy, utility cap inclusion, calendar impact on other platforms, and lease duration acceptability. In the call, these were addressed sequentially over several minutes of conversation with Bryant. On the platform, if these verification points are spread across multiple screens or require clicking into sub-sections, the host cannot perform the holistic assessment that proposals demand. Saffer's principle that 'Feedback Illuminates the Rules' means every rule the host cares about must be visible at the moment of decision. June said 'I need to know who they are and what type of people' and 'tell them it's something they have to decide quickly' -- she needs speed AND thoroughness, which are only compatible if all information is on one surface.
elements.solution: Design the proposal review screen as a single-surface verification checklist that displays every host-defined rule alongside its current status. (1) Guest vetting: show a summary card with employment status, vetting completion indicator, and link to full profile. Do not force the host to navigate to a separate vetting page. (2) Pricing accuracy: display the exact rent, deposit, cleaning fee, and any conditional rules (utility cap) as the host defined them, with a visual confirmation that these match the host's listing. (3) Calendar impact: show the proposed dates and flag which other platforms need to be blocked. (4) Lease terms: show duration, extension option, and start date in the host's original language. (5) Payment guarantee: show the guarantee as a visible, branded element -- not fine print. (6) A single 'Accept' action after visual verification, not a multi-step approval wizard. The proposal screen is a decision surface, and all inputs to that decision must be present on it.

evidence.quote: I need to know who they are and what type of people. I don't want Connie in the house.
evidence.insight: Guest vetting information is a non-negotiable verification requirement. The host will not accept a proposal without visible evidence that vetting has occurred. LinkedIn profiles were offered but may not match the host's mental model of 'documentation.'

evidence.quote: We've vetted both Ariel and Amber... payments are guaranteed to you as the landlord... even in the case that a guest missed a payment or didn't pay, you still get paid.
evidence.insight: Two critical rules -- vetting completion and payment guarantee -- were communicated verbally during the call. On the proposal screen, these must be visible as verified indicators, not text descriptions that the host has to read and trust.

evidence.source: microinteractions-rules-feedback.txt, Ch. 4, Feedback Illuminates the Rules, p. 86
evidence.quote: Feedback Illuminates the Rules.
evidence.insight: Every rule the host set (pricing, vetting, utility cap, calendar) must be illuminated on the proposal screen. If a rule is not visible at the moment of decision, it effectively does not exist for the host.

evidence.quote: Visual feedback is the most effective form.
evidence.insight: Vetting status, payment guarantee, and pricing accuracy should be communicated through visual indicators (checkmarks, status badges, color coding), not through paragraphs of explanatory text. The host should be able to verify all rules at a glance.

elements.user_goal: See everything I need to verify about a proposal -- guest quality, my pricing, my rules, calendar impact -- on one screen so I can make a fast, confident accept or decline decision.
elements.company_goal: Increase proposal acceptance rate and reduce time-to-acceptance by eliminating the information scattering that causes hosts to defer decisions or contact support for clarification.
elements.time_budget: The host should be able to scan all verification points in under 30 seconds and complete the accept/decline action in under 60 seconds total.
anti_goals: DO NOT spread proposal information across multiple tabs or pages. Every verification point must be on the primary proposal screen.
DO NOT hide the payment guarantee in terms and conditions. It is the platform's strongest trust signal and must be visually prominent.
DO NOT require the host to click into a separate vetting report. A summary with key indicators should be visible inline, with a detail link for hosts who want more.
DO NOT present the accept action as a multi-step wizard. It should be a single action after visual verification is complete.
elements.success_metric: Time from proposal notification to host accept/decline action. Target: median under 4 hours. Secondary: percentage of proposals accepted without a support contact or agent call. Target: 70%.
